intro: Gasteranthus adenocalyx, commonly known as the "tongue-of-the-angel," is a striking plant native to the Andes mountains of South America. It is a member of the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its vibrant, showy flowers that resemble a tongue or a lip. The plant produces bright yellow or orange flowers with a distinctive, swollen base that resembles a mouth, hence its common name. It thrives in cool, humid environments and is often found in cloud forests. Gasteranthus adenocalyx is prized for its ornamental value and is cultivated in botanical gardens and by enthusiasts for its unique appearance.
